title: CaCO3 in eggshells - equation for reacting species

content.description:
An experiment is performed to measure the mass percent of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in eggshells. Five different samples of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of known mass react with an excess of <math alttext="2.0 molar H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in identical sealed, rigid reaction vessels. The pressure of the gas produced is measured with a pressure gauge attached to the reaction vessel. Since the reaction is exothermic, the reaction system is cooled to its original temperature before the pressure is recorded. The experimental data are used to create the calibration line below.

The experiment is repeated with an eggshell sample, and the experimental data are recorded in the table below.

Mass of eggshell sample
 <math alttext="0.200 gram" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Pressure prior to reaction
 <math alttext="0.800 atmosphere" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.800</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Pressure at completion of reaction
 <math alttext="0.870 atmosphere" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.870</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Which of the following equations best represents the species that react and the species that are produced when <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are combined?

choices.label: <math alttext="2 H with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus C a C O 3, solid, react to produce C a with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous, plus H 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2 H with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus C a C O 3, solid, react to produce C a with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, plus C O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2 H with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus C a C O 3, solid, react to produce C a with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus 2 O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, plus C O, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>CO</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2 H C l, aqueous, plus C a C O 3, solid, react to produce C a with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, plus C O 2, gas, plus 2 C l with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext></mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="2 H with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus C a C O 3, solid, react to produce C a with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, plus C O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>CaC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 5.E: Determine a balanced chemical equation for a given chemical phenomenon.
